Yes, we use GET /settings to inject device information. The request will fail if any of these fields is misconfigured.
We don't have a concept of "disabling" the tokenization. Once 4Go is configured to tokenize on device, it cannot be changed,
unless you replace the device and switch to tokenization in UTG.
We can generate tokens on previous version of P2PE devices, but only in UTG. S920 is our official device to tokenize in the device.
I hope that answers the questions regarding tokenization. As for the architectural questions, I am not the best person
and my answers will be incomplete.

Let me summarize the process of configuration and tokenization:
1.  Configuration
 a.  During installation and first run 4Go will obtain 4Go license, UTG license, merchant configuration and iTOKEN merchant ID from Shift4 services.
 b. Lookup the customer in UTG and confirm that the merchant is set up for iTOKEN and a device is assigned to it.
 C.  4Go will extract device serial number, encryption ID and other properties.
d. 4Go will use the data from Step B and C to construct the following JSON object

{"deviceinfo":
{
  "devices": [
}

{
  "deviceID": "[REDACTED]",
  "encryptionId": "[REDACTED]",
  "firmwareVersion": "[REDACTED]",
  "make": "[REDACTED]",
  "model": "[REDACTED]",
  "p2pe": false,
  "serialNumber": "[REDACTED]",
   "terminalId": "[REDACTED]",
   "terminalOsType": "[REDACTED]"
}
]

e. 	This object is posted to UTG.

f. 	UTG will extract the device serial number and finds the device in its own database.

g. UTG uses the "make", "mode1", "termina1Id" and "termina10sType" to compose a database key.
h. The key from the previous step is used to lookup a [REDACTED] in the UTG database and inject the
following

[REDACTED]

into the database record.
i. UTG will replace the "termina1Id" with the ID mentioned above and return the modified "deviceinfo"

2.  Tokenization
 a.  4Go intercept PIN pad communication and once swiped the card 4Go will execute the following ommand to retrieve a token from S920.

{"header":{"applicationSender":"APPJDSLSQA","authentication":{"deviceSerial":"[REDACTED]
","licenseId":"[REDACTED]
","utcTimestamp":"2020-02-
06T07:33:19-05:00"},"protocolVersion":"[REDACTED]","requestType":"UTG"},"request":{"trace" :{"e2eTraceId":"[REDACTED]", "relay TraceId":"[REDACTED]"},"utg":{"action":"TOKENIZE","encryptionId":"[REDACTED]
","format Preserving":"false","orderId":" [REDACTED]", "strictMode":"TRUE","timeout":25000,"trackData":" ;[REDACTED]?", "type":"CARD"}}}

b.  S920 will forward the request to UTG.

c.  UTG will parse the data, use the device serial number and encryption ID in its own database to find the corresponding device.

d. 	If UTG finds the device and the decryption of the track data succeeds, it will generate a token and return it back to S920.

e.  	S920 will pass the token to 4Go, which in turn will extract the necessary data and place it in Micros E7 format as shown below.

Yes, we use P2PE device S920 to tokenize card swipe. The actual token is generated by UTG, S920 works as a proxy between
4Go and UTG. 4Go has a simplistic concept of a P2PE device. The only requirement for us internally is to have a device
serial number and URL to send the request to. Everything else is up to the device itself.

Re: [External] Re: 4Go P2PE Status and integration

We configure the communication between UTG and the P2PE device using /api/settings endpoint as shown in the
attached document. The configuration steps are pretty standard for all P2PE devices and involve mostly extracting data from
UTG and posting it back to UTG for it to configure internal device information.

The tokenization part uses the same endpoint, but the body is different. 4Go simply posts the encrypted track data along with
device information (serial number, encryption ID, etc.) to a common URL. Then it is up to the REDACTED hosted device
application to establish a connection to UTG, decrypt the data, generate a token and send it back. This process uses the
standard UTG API and once configured properly, it becomes completely transparent for 4Go.
